doc.title: Marvell Technology, Inc.
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Marvell Technology Inc. Lower CY26 growth confidence downgrade to Neutral. 78 POMarvell Technology Inc. Lower CY26 growt_2025-08-29

passages.text: Rating Change: NEUTRAL | PO: 78.00 USD | Price: 77.23 USD

Lower confidence in CY26 AI growth, cutting sets by \(10\% +\) We downgrade MRVL stock to Neutral from Buy, lower FY27/28E (roughly CY26/27) pf- EPS by \(10\% /14\%\) to \(\) 3.20/\(\) 3.67\(, and take our PO to\) \ \(78\) from \(\) 90\(, based on 24x CY26E PE (vs. 25x prior), still within its historical 13x - 46x range and 3 - yr 24x median PE. Unlike prior calls, we did not hear the same level of confidence/visibility about MRVL's AI growth prospects in the near/medium term. At this point we sense incrementally higher uncertainty around both: 1) the timing of MRVL's new (Microsoft Maia) project (could be more FY28/CY27E rather than 2HFY27/CY26E), and 2) Share in next- gen 3nm Amazon project. As a result, we lower CY26 data center growth to mid- teens YoY from 23- 25% YoY prior. In our view, a Neutral rating better reflects/balances MRVL's opportunity/ breadth of IP with lumpiness in AI sales, customer centration risks, and strong competition for custom chip (ASIC) sockets.

MRVL: 1) slightly missed Q2 data center (grew \(3\%\) QoQ vs. MSD guide), 2) guided Q3 data center flat (vs. cons \(+5\%\) QoQ) on slowdown in custom ASIC offset by growth in optical, and 3) suggested (but did not quantify) recovery in Q4 data center sales. All- in, we estimate DC is exiting FY26/CY25E at a \(\) 100\(mn lower quarterly run- rate, and hence a\) \ \(400mn drag on projected FY27/CY26 sales. Second, unlike the FQ1 earnings call where mgmt explicitly stressed existing and new custom wins, the affirmation was missing in the Q2 call. Beyond the DC drag, MRVL is also facing pressure from its auto segment divestiture and lower consumer sales, hence what was supposed to be a \(- 20\%\) topline growth rate is now a still decent but lower mid- teens growth- rate outlook. The growth- rate potentially improves in FY28/CY27E, but it's too early to make that call.

MRVL stock had already underperformed peers YTD, down \(- 30\%\) vs SOX/peers up \(+30\%\) so some EPS reset was expected. Second, at after hours price, MRVL is trading at 20x- \(21x\) PE, which tends to provide a floor to compute stocks with strong breadth of IP. Lastly, the \(\) 2.5bn\(proceeds from auto divestiture can provide buybacks/potential M&A.

Marvell is a leading fabless supplier of high performance standard and semi- custom products with a core strength in developing complex System- on- Chip architectures, and integrating analog, mixed- signal, and digital signal processing functionality. Marvell's broad portfolio of IP spans computing, optics, networking, storage, and security and addresses the enterprise, cloud, telecom, auto, and industrial markets.

We rate MRVL Neutral. While MRVL has successfully transformed into an IP powerhouse with a suite of data center silicon, electro- optics, and networking IP, we also see lumpiness in AI compute sales, customer concentration, and strong AI competition balancing out the near- term potential. We still note opportunities across cloud data centers, 5G infrastructure, advanced autos, enterprise networking and security markets could drive 20- 25% long- term sales and 25- 30% long- term EPS growth.

Our \(578\) PO is based on 24x FY27E/CY26E pf- EPS, in- line with historical 24x median and within historical 13x- 46x range.

Upside risks: 1) Faster than anticipated ramp/visibility in major custom ASIC projects, 2) Continued growth in DSP- based pluggable market, versus new LPO/LRO techs, 3) Share gains in emerging AEC/CPO/scale- up switch markets against incumbents.

Downside risks: 1) Continued lack of visibility in key custom ASIC projects, particularly in the next- gen 3nm chip at AWS, 2) Competition in AI compute, with merchant vendors continuing to proliferate and ASIC incumbent AVGO winning many of the large hyperscaler/AI customers, 3) cyclical industry risks including potential slowdown in legacy storage, enterprise networking, carrier markets.
